Child Bride (1938) is a provocative American drama written and directed by Harry Revier and produced by Raymond L. Friedgen. Starring Shirley Mills, Angelo Rossitto, Warner Richmond, Diana Durrell and others, this film was promoted as an educational exposÃ© about child marriage in remote Ozarks communities. Colorized and restored, this edition gives modern viewers in the United States, Europe, and beyond a clearer, more accessible look at a deeply controversial piece of early exploitation cinema.

Child Bride, also known as Child Brides, Child Bride of the Ozarks and Dust to Dust (US reissue titles),[citation needed] is a 1938 American drama film written and directed by Harry Revier, and produced by Raymond L. Friedgen. It was promoted as educational in an attempt to draw attention to the lack of laws banning child marriage in many states.

The Ozarks, also known as the Ozark Mountains, Ozark Highlands or Ozark Plateau.

Plot Summary:
Jennie Colton (Shirley Mills), a twelve-year-old living in a secluded mountain region, becomes the reluctant focal point of a dangerous tradition when the townâ€™s older men believe it acceptable to marry underage girls. Miss Carol (Diana Durrell), a schoolteacher who grew up in the same hills but was educated elsewhere, returns home determined to abolish child marriage. She clashes with Jake Bolby (Warner Richmond), a predatory older man who eyes Jennie. Jennieâ€™s father, Ira Colton (George Humphreys), tries to protect her as threats escalate. After Jennieâ€™s father dies and under pressure from Bolby, her mother (Ma Colton, Dorothy Carrol) is coerced into allowing a marriage arrangement. A key sequence involving Jennie swimming nude (filmed when the actress was twelve) stirred scandal, and eventually Jennie is rescued when Angelo the dwarf (Angelo Rossitto) intervenes. The climax reveals the marriage was made illegal by recent laws, but not in time to prevent the emotional damage.

Film Significance:
Child Bride is notorious both for its social message and its exploitation tactics. It claimed to highlight the lack of laws banning child marriage, but it also used shock valueâ€”particularly the nude swimming scene with a pre-teenâ€”to attract attention. The film was denied PCA (Hays Code) approval for its subject matter and nudity yet continued to circulate via independent/exploitation channels. It has endured as a film that many see as ethically problematic but historically relevant, especially for discussions around censorship, exploitation cinema, and societal change.

sources.title: Child Bride (1938) EXPLOITATION
sources.description:
Stars: Shirley Mills, Bob Bollinger, Warner Richmond
 Director: Harry Revier

 Schoolteacher in a rural community campaigns to stop the practice of older men marrying young, underage girls. This film is partly based on the true story of a 9 year old girl, Eunice Winstead who married a 22 year old man in 1937 in Tennessee.
